reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: REDUCING DEMAND FOR ILLEGAL WILDLIFE AND PRODUCTS IN THE UNITED STATES. Combating Wildlife Trafficking by Improving Understanding of Impacts and Drivers to Help Reduce Demand for Illegal Wildlife Products in the Greater Seattle Area

description.narrative: Conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. Programs in this element should be integrated with the Agriculture Area under Economic Growth and Conflict Mitigation and Reconciliation Area under the Peace and Security Category, when applicable and appropriate.

This award strives to conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. This includes REDUCING DEMAND FOR ILLEGAL WILDLIFE AND PRODUCTS IN THE UNITED STATES. This project will assess citizen knowledge of wildlife trafficking in the greater Seattle, Washington area by targeting the one million seasonal cruise ship passengers using the Port of Seattle and the over one million yearly visitors to Woodland Park Zoo. This project is intended to help conserve two groups of species - globally iconic species threatened by illegal wildlife trafficking as identified by Washington State’s Initiative 1401 (such as tigers, elephants, and rhinos), and key threatened species from Alaska’s illegal wildlife trade (such as walrus and whales) by addressing consumer demand. Specific project components include: 1) to collect and assess existing information (including through citizen surveys and through working with USFWS Law Enforcement and other agencies) on wildlife trafficking in and around Seattle to determine the types and scale of the trade, the particular species involved in the trade, the consumer groups involved, and the factors influencing their current attitudes/behavior; 2) develop strategic and focused education and behavior change initiatives focused on the Seattle cruise ship industry and Woodland Park Zoo, and 3) evaluate the effectiveness of these awareness-building activities and messaging..
